report from the online meetup hosted by e-editions on 2020-10-20 (MT)
related issue #2035: naming and description of TEI Simple Print and TEI Lite
more introductory material is needed (much is outdated, examples and available tooling).
no linear progression through the body of TEI materials. Reference material can be baffling for beginners.

Examples should be complete documents (e.g. as provided by TEI Publisher community) because of the problem of relying on small code blocks and the need to see the bigger picture.
Need for a curated repository of examples in different languages (as discussed in i18n group too).
Spanish (TTHub) and Japanese training materials are very good: can these be brought together on the TEI website?
Can the TEI website be a better resource for this? Invite community members to contribute to a series of WordPress posts.
TEI website has a list of pointers to projects, but that is less than ideal for this purpose for a variety of reasons.
Schema is a secondary matter
SB, at least, strongly objects to the name “Vanilla”

Potential Next Steps?
TEI Council should review the current introductory material and try to curate and filter some of the older material to ensure that it is relevant to current Guidelines.
Encourage creation of ‘Road Not Taken’ examples? Explanations of decisions and alternates not chosen.
Can we encourage some material to be written on the whole process, from encoding TEI documents to publishing them?

div.head: Report: remove @version on TEI and teiCorpus

We should continue to develop datatypes for semantic, and maybe calendar, versioning.

discuss at the next Council meeting.

div.head: Invitation for TEI liaison from ISO TC37/SC3

list.item: Invited guest: Laurent Romary
TC37/SC3 does terminology management systems.
TBX format for exchanging terminological information used in translation management systems.
New chair of SC3 wants to establish better interfaces and liaisons with other groups.
LB was liaison with SC4.
Liaison could be appointed each year within Council. The responsibility is to read or at least skim proposals and messages, and keep Council updated.
The Council as a group can provide feedback on ISO proposals.
Some proposals are about defining TBX in ODD. TEI could bring in some ISO terminology for the Dictionary chapter for example.

SB asks if SC3 is reviewing documents only within the group of representatives or whether they can consult with the TEI-C. LR: they would inform representatives. The designated contact person has responsibility to ask back in own organisation. Council: We have to appoint someone.
General meetings are every 6 months. Working groups may meet more frequently depending on projects. There is a plenary every June on terminology and term extraction systems and methods.
Other TEI connections: SC4 on feature structures where the TEI–represented by Lou Burnard–already has a liaison. Others, Lexical Markup Framework (for lexical databases) mention TEI.
Request is for a liaison with SC3 working group, but probably our new liaison would be connected with SC4 too, as Lou Burnard has already agreed with the Board to step aside.
Timeframe: when do they need a liaison? Maybe as soon as we have Council election results.
NC is interested, pending re-election to Council.
Council should check every January about the status of our ISO liaison, and make the liaison(s) public on the TEI website.
Other liaisons to investigate: DocBook? JATS?
Action on MS to write to Kathryn Tomasek to inform her that NC will be the representative of TEI-C.
official
unofficial (those Council need not appoint or update)
strategic partnerships

RV put together an Airtable (cloud servi for the glossary of terms of the TEI from German and Japanese glossary + i18n.xml file. The working group discussed how to use the glossary. Start translation work on specs and if we encounter something to translate add it to the glossary.
Glossary https://airtable.com/tblzh2JnHxAy44ThO
Gimena del Rio Riande wants to start with first steps at a workshop in November.

MT organisational question. Is there a plan for the translation work?
Spanish, German, and Japanese groups were the first to get involved, starting with the Scholarly Communications Institute in 2019. Japanese group is very active with translation work. i18n group is very open, but hard to organize due to time zone differences.
Need to work out how the TEI website can be a better hub for finding out ongoing translation efforts. And have multilingual landing pages.
Should become an internationalization SIG instead of working group eventually.
MT: TEI Publisher (with 17 languages involved) has a crowdsourcing translation workflow where atomized particles are translated for the interface. Bracket off untranslatable code like {{count}}. Make it easy for people to contribute: Need a lot of preparation for that including good access to open source tools like Crowdin, and lots of motivational work to find people!
PS and HC: how to work on specs translations. Crowdin would not work so well for this. But we will need to work on interface translation, too. Is there GitHub integration for translation crowd-sourcing software?

cell.p: Subgroup agrees this is a good proposal. Possibly we revisit @status on att.transcriptional, the attribute name is not appropriate to its intended use.

Possibly: change att.docStatus, such that we redefine the @status attribute, and change correction. The @status defined on that element is a narrowed-down version of what we would want on a global scale.

Work on describing what would need to happen to make att.docStatus global and revisit.

cell.ref: place should be allowed to contain address as a child.

cell.p: Subgroup thinks location serves to signal address as a specific location just like a geo-coordinate reference, and does not think we should allow place to contain address as a direct child. Location info could be subject to change in reference to a place (volcanic eruption, geopolitical change of street names, etc.)

13.3.4 “Places” defines place as having a name and a location. country, region, and settlement are all specializations of the generic placeName element and are therefore allowed as children of place. address is not semantic sugar for placeName so it should remain in location.

However, HC notes that this section is unsophisticated and may need updating. Subgroup recommends we reject James’ idea for now, and also consider revisiting the language about place and location in 13.3.4.
Council: Close with explanation. Open a new ticket for HC to to work on 13.3.4. DONE: #2042.

cell.ref: Nested vColl elements

cell.p: Subgroup leans toward clarifying the Guidelines prose to match the content model, which permits indirect nesting of vColl within fs. cell.ref: versionDate attribute needs more constraint

cell.p: Subgroup thinks this should be green to implement the Schematron solution to constrain @versionDate to a date after 2008 or at least a date using a 4-digit year, and before the day after tomorrow. We also need to change the description of @versionDate.

Council agrees that the constraint is important for the schema that constraints P5 and its customizations (i.e., p5odds and tei_customization), but is split on whether it should be a part of P5 or not.
Might be good to have a more restrictive datatype, maybe like teidata.dateTime, for use in documentation. Require a full date or a dateTime, four-digit year. Post Unix start date: 1970-01-01?
Status:Go and Needs discussion. Ask SB + MB to come up with a good plan for combining a datatype + Schematron check.

cell.ref: Element/@ident without English glosses or descs

cell.p: Subgroup thinks that everything about att.translatable is wrong and needs to be rewritten.

Subgroup also is mildly in favor of requiring an English gloss for every specification element, whether it is “needed” or not by the current rules. That would a) give us a place to put the @versionDate for the translators, b) make it so that all languages are treated equally, and
c) allow p5odds to require a gloss child of elementSpec, etc.

It does mean someone would have to write XSLT to generate the needed <gloss xml:lang=”en”>, which is easy, but what would their @versionDate values be? (Suggestion: take the newest of all the other glosses. Yes, there is a small chance it has been changed since, but how would we catch that?)
d) Having an English gloss present where it wasn’t before will help the i18n translation process to have a ‘hook’ for translations.
SB thinks that a blue sky conversation is needed about idents and namespaces in general (may be a P6 thing).
PS: Maybe wait for i18n group to share their workflow for identifying what needs translation? Discussion: Adding glosses should help the i18n group.
SB: What we really need is the date the @ident was last changed?
PS suggests we change our styleguides for updating the Guidelines to ensure English gloss is present.
Council: Green for SB to require the English gloss.
